articles.headline: A Dam in Syria Was on a ‘No-Strike’ List. The U.S. Bombed It Anyway.
articles.snippet: A military report warned that striking the giant structure could cause tens of thousands of deaths.
articles.abstract: A military report warned that striking the giant structure could cause tens of thousands of deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: Near the height of the war against the Islamic State in Syria, a sudden riot of explosions rocked the country’s largest dam, a towering, 18-story structure on the Euphrates River that held back a 25-mile-long reservoir above a valley where hundreds of thousands of people lived.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps, Azmat Khan and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Atlanta D.A. Requests Special Grand Jury in Trump Election Inquiry
articles.snippet: The prosecutor, Fani T. Willis of Fulton County, Ga., is investigating possible election interference by the former president and his allies.
articles.abstract: The prosecutor, Fani T. Willis of Fulton County, Ga., is investigating possible election interference by the former president and his allies.
articles.lead_paragraph: A district attorney in Atlanta on Thursday asked a judge to convene a special grand jury to help a criminal investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election results in Georgia.
articles.byline: By Maggie Astor and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: 80 Years Ago the Nazis Planned the ‘Final Solution.’ It Took 90 Minutes.
articles.snippet: As Germany observes the anniversary of the Wannsee Conference, witnesses of the Nazi era are dying and antisemitism is resurgent in Europe and the United States.
articles.abstract: As Germany observes the anniversary of the Wannsee Conference, witnesses of the Nazi era are dying and antisemitism is resurgent in Europe and the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — On Jan. 20, 1942, 15 high-ranking officials of the Nazi bureaucracy met in a villa on Lake Wannsee on the western edge of Berlin. Nibbles were served and washed down with cognac. There was only one point on the agenda: “The organizational, logistical and material steps for a final solution of the Jewish question in Europe.”

articles.headline: Intel to Invest at Least $20 Billion in New Chip Factories in Ohio
articles.snippet: Building up U.S. chip production has been a focus of lawmakers and companies alike amid a global shortage of the crucial components.
articles.abstract: Building up U.S. chip production has been a focus of lawmakers and companies alike amid a global shortage of the crucial components.
articles.lead_paragraph: Intel has selected Ohio for a new chip manufacturing complex that would cost at least $20 billion, ramping up an effort to increase U.S. production of computer chips as users grapple with a lingering shortage of the vital components.

articles.headline: Racial Turmoil Mars Signs of Progress at the U.S. Mint
articles.snippet: A new internal report found that Black employees felt marginalized at the Treasury agency that produces the nation’s coins.
articles.abstract: A new internal report found that Black employees felt marginalized at the Treasury agency that produces the nation’s coins.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States Mint celebrated a milestone this month when it announced the first shipment of a new batch of quarters bearing the image of the writer and poet Maya Angelou, the first Black woman to be depicted on the 25-cent coin.

articles.headline: How Much Are You Willing to Pay for a Burrito?
articles.snippet: The pandemic has led to the largest price spikes at fast-food restaurants in two decades.
articles.abstract: The pandemic has led to the largest price spikes at fast-food restaurants in two decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a chilly Tuesday afternoon this month, James Marsh stopped by a Chipotle near his suburban Chicago home to grab something to eat.

articles.headline: Back to School, but Still Learning Online
articles.snippet: Federal stimulus dollars are dedicated to helping students recover from virtual schooling. Many districts are spending some of that money on virtual tutoring.
articles.abstract: Federal stimulus dollars are dedicated to helping students recover from virtual schooling. Many districts are spending some of that money on virtual tutoring.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Education Secretary Miguel Cardona appeared before Congress in September to promote the Biden administration’s stimulus funding for schools, he promised tutoring to help students make up missed learning, as well as an end to instruction through screens.

articles.headline: China Holds the Line on ‘Zero Covid,’ but Some Wonder for How Long
articles.snippet: More people are being caught up in the country’s virus-control dragnet. Some think the no-tolerance policy is unsustainable.
articles.abstract: More people are being caught up in the country’s virus-control dragnet. Some think the no-tolerance policy is unsustainable.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a glitzy Shanghai shopping district, about 40 people who happened to be at a Uniqlo store were informed that they would be spending the night there. A suspected Covid case had been traced to the shop.
articles.byline: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien

articles.headline: Zero-Covid Policy Shakes Hong Kong’s Economy and Its ‘Soul’
articles.snippet: Businesses that held on through several outbreaks are now trembling as the highflying metropolitan hub struggles with supply chain issues and a relentless approach to the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Businesses that held on through several outbreaks are now trembling as the highflying metropolitan hub struggles with supply chain issues and a relentless approach to the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Perry Lam felt confident that his business had weathered the worst of the pandemic. Several rounds of bar closures in Hong Kong had dimmed the city’s vibrant nightlife, threatening to destroy his brewery. But things seemed better late last year.

articles.headline: You Quit. I Quit. We All Quit. And It’s Not a Coincidence.
articles.snippet: Why the decision to leave a job can become contagious.
articles.abstract: Why the decision to leave a job can become contagious.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something infectious is spreading through the work force. Its symptoms present in a spate of two-week notices. Its transmission is visible in real time. And few bosses seem to know how to inoculate their staff against this quitagion.
